name: British Opium Trade in China
description: Britain's forced export of opium to China, causing widespread addiction and social devastation. When China tried to ban the trade, Britain launched the Opium Wars (1839-42, 1856-60) to force continued imports, eventually seizing Hong Kong and extracting massive reparations.

mortality.note: Direct war deaths low (~20-50k across both Opium Wars). True harm was addiction: 10-15 million addicts by 1900, economic devastation, societal breakdown. Contributed to instability leading to Taiping Rebellion (20-30M dead). Mortality figures vastly understate actual harm.

rationales.systematic_intensity: State-backed East India Company trade, two Opium Wars to force market access.
rationales.profit: Pure profit motive: opium solved British trade deficit with China. Vast wealth extracted.
rationales.ideology: Free trade ideology used to justify drug trafficking. No ethnic targeting.
rationales.complicity: British government, merchants, and consumers benefited. Addiction framed as Chinese weakness.

analysis.pattern_note: State-sponsored drug trafficking enforced by military. Britain grew opium in India, forced China to accept imports via gunboat diplomacy. When China resisted, Royal Navy attacked. Resulted in 'unequal treaties', Hong Kong cession, and millions of addicts. Highest profit score in dataset - pure extraction with ideological cover ('free trade'). Shows how economic violence can devastate without high direct mortality.
analysis.root_causes: Trade deficit, corporate greed (East India Company), imperial arrogance

sources.title: The Opium War: Drugs, Dreams and the Making of Modern China
